In the absence of specific intelligence from any
quarter which calls for comment, 1t may be atogeth-
er useless task to make rapid survey of the ex-
isting political relations of Europe.


The extreme boundaries of the Continent pre-
sents the chief materials for argument. In the north
and in the south, as II as throughout the whole OF
the Central States, there is profound repose but
Portugal and Spain in the west, and Turkey in
the east, are the theatres where important events
have occurred, and where events Of still greater i'm
poriance threaten to occur.


Portugal approaches the termination OF her crisis,
or rather. we should say approaches one of the ter


limitations of those vsisstudes to which she has been
exposed Don Miguel at length returns. to assume
the vlceregal sceptre, and administer the govern
ment, in the spirit Of the constitution bestowed by
Don Pedro. His assumption of royal power under


the limitation granted, as it will be by the Soveregns
more Immediately in alliance with Portugal sets at
rest political sophsm. upon which calculations Of
a far different character had been made. The in
tesrity and legitimacy of the Sovereignty. as in-
herent in the person of Don Pedro, thus estab-
lished and they will consequently, become PrIn-
ciplc or test. by which to try the actions OF Don
Miguel. We are not, we confess, very sangune as
-.,sarA to Portugal. lhere are
more elements of discOrd in that country than the
Infant, with the best and most sincere intentions.
can either extnguish control. 1.-The is sincere.
and if he acts with proper vlgor, more may be accom-
plished than seem, probable.


The situation of Spain is one of still greater com
plexity and difficulty not merely as concerns Spain
herself but as her destiny is closely connected with
the policy of France. Until order and tranquility be
resored--until something like stability is impaired
to the Government-there will never be wanting
plausible pretexs for the interference, direct indi
rect of that country; and this interference, assume
what shape it may. will bring into discussion with our
own government many delicate and embarrassing
questions. An invasion tolerated rather than appro-
we'd. by England, has ended by leaving his Catho-
lie Majesty in worse situation than it found him.
What power Ferdinand really possessed land It is


little enough) is held by the sword it is the result
of perpetual conflict between different classes OF
his subjects, and different authorities in the State
foreign army, though it does not overawe, at least
coerces the multiplied factions into which Spain is
divided when that army is withdrawn, as we have

letter published in the New York Commercial,
dated Washington, Dec. &, says


There was some conversation yesterday among
members about a suitable candidate for Vice Pre-
sident. Several gentlemen were mentioned, among
whom were Gov. Shulze, Gov. Morrow, Gen. iar-
rison, Chief Justice Savage, and Gov Pleasants.-
There seems to be desire ofpreserving the usage
which locates one Of the two highest offices IN the
gift of the people OF the North, and the other in
the South. lfthis principle should govern, think
Gov. Peasants will be nominated. He is. as you
know, a gentleman of fine attainments, much en-
deared 10 Virginia by various and faithful public
services. He is represented to be exceedingly
aniable in private life, and is known to be endowed
with exalted public virtues.


P. S--l passed the evening where the subject
of the Vice Presidency was discussed. Unless cir
cumstances now unseen, shall change the views OF
the friends of the administration, Gov. P. is the
man. Hei is, and has been, warm friend. The


canldate idr v President will be nominated by the


state conveAons as they meet to nominate electors

Extract of IA letter from an intelligent and infuen-
tia man 10 Ohio to his friend in Baltimore, dated


December l., 1897.


81 think it certain as any event yet to happen,
that the vote of Ohio Will be for Adams by at least
10000 majority. The noisy clustering Of the Jack
son men would induce strangers to believe all OHIO
was for Jackson. Not so-in no event and under
no circumstances can Jackson get an elector in this
State. My advices from various parts ofkentucky
are of the most cheering and gratifying character
the vote of that State will beyond all doubt. be tor
Adams. The friends of the Administration in that
and indeed in all the Western States, are organizing
themselves and will hereafter move in solid column.
They have too long relied overwhelming strength
and the goodness of their cause-this will no
longer answer in these times Of bargain and intrigue
Let every man who is not ashamed TO avow himself
the friend of our enlightened administration put
forth his strength and do his duty, fearlessy and
manfully, and all will be WE'LL"

"When we look round and see the peace and
plenty which regns throughout the ian0 the ripe

merce; the hardy plough the swift shuttle, and
all the prosperous branches of industry when we
see education extended, and learning prevail reli-
gon, unmxed with bigotry, encouraged, and good
faith rewarded when the blessings Of health have
been also secured to us--our gratitude, tor all these
signal benefits, should be sincere, unbounded, and
deyout.

The Treasury Report which we presented yester-

abundant revenue aud diminishing debt. About
sixteen millions and nalf of the principal OF the

without new burdens but during the same TIME
nearly twelve mi lions Of interest have been regu
ary paid while all the expenditures for the public
service have been going on, and III some cases extra
ordinary appropriations have been made. Inc no
minal debt will, on the LIST January 1898, appeal
to be 81 millions of dollars but, OF this amount
seven millions are invested in the stock OF the Banl
of the United States, which, under all clrcum
stances will be worth the cost; SO. that sum is no
in fact debt, but beneficial investment whicl
produces good interest. Then there is furthe
sum OF i3 millions Of per cents, which as it can
not by law be bought by the Sinking Fund at pric
over Is per cent. will not with the interest Of mt
ney exceed S per cent? be paid oft, and ma
therefore be deemed rather as constituting permi
nent per cent. annuities, than part of the debt
be redeemed as soon as possible With these d'
ductions the actual debt will amount only to Fort
seven millions of dollars that is, the whole del
of the United States, is only equal in amount
about one quarter Of the expenditures Of the Briis

CONDITIONS. S.

A WIFE's APPEAL TO HER HUSBAND.
why heave that sigh my only love9
Is then the scene SO sad before thee,
That nothing can The thoughts remove
That spread their darknlng influence DER thee:
Believe me thou ar, still as dear
AS when thou vast III youth and riches.
Oh! wipe away tina; starting tear;
1t Sit IS thy WIFE beseecEcs
Oh. think upon thosc early days,
When thou to STRAIN sung would'st listen,
When thy fond look was my best praise,
And with sweet tears thine eyes would glisten.
Believe me love 'tis still The same,
That fruit IS here tho fall'n the blossom!
Time tempers, but not cools the fame
That burns within the faithful bosom.
There is hought may still beguile,
In joy or grief we're never parted,
And oh could but see thee smile
should not be quite broken hearted.
Oh! cease to heave the struggling sigh!
Oh! dash away that tear my dearest!
Believe me, happier Tia, 5 are nigh;
When night is darkest, dawn is nearest;
Look on our infants artless vile,
That strives to take away thy sorrow,
Can'st thou not from that bab sweet smile,
The ray Of joy 10 cheer thee borrows


There is something in my breast


That says we are not quite forsakcn


That says "nce more we shalt be blest,
And joys soft tone again shall walen.


Prrchlnce the parting beam Of life,


Shal shed peaceful sunshine DER us;


Th n hand in hand we'll quit the strife,


With bright thornless 'ath before us.

The sentiment of Virginia, towards the admins

FRIDAY, December FL, 1927.

The airy ship at anchor rides;
Proudly she heaves her painted sides,


Impatient OF delay
And now her silken form expands,
She springs aloft, she bursts her bands.


She floats upon her way.
How swift! for now see her sail
High mounted on the v,ewess gale,


And speeding up the sky,
And now a speck in etner tosl--
A moment seen, a moment lost


She cheats my dazzle,i eye.
Bright wonder, thee no Tapping wing,
No abouring oar. no bounding spring.


Urge ON thy fleet career;
by native buoyalcy lmpclled,
Thy easy fight was smoothly held


Along the silent sphere.
No cuiling mist at close of light,
No meteor on the breast of night,


No cloud at breezy dawn;
No leaf adown the summer tide
More eHortless is seen to glide,


Or shadow DER the lawn.
Yet thee, e'en then, the destined hour
Snail summon from thy airy tower,
With haccid sides that droop forlorn,


Thy breath atherlal spent.
Thus daring fancy's plume sublime
Thus loves bright wings are clippd by time


Thus hope, her soul eate,
Exhales amid this grosscr air.
Thus lghtest hearts are bowed by care,
And genius yields to fate.
THE BALLOON.
By Miss Lucy AKIN.

tesrity and legitimacy of the Sovereignty. as in-

lished and they will consequently, become PrIn-
ciplc or test. by which to try the actions OF Don

can either extnguish control. 1.-The is sincere.

leved to be one of the mos. splendid little works O
taste ever published in this country it contains i
elegant engraviugs, descriptive of Cats Kill falls. III
conderoga Delaware Water Gap, Bournouese War
ror Moonlight, SC. SC. &c.

full articles.headline: A wIFE's APPEAL TO HER HUSBAND.
full articles.article:
A WIFE's APPEAL TO HER HUSBAND.
why heave that sigh my only love9
Is then the scene SO sad before thee,
That nothing can The thoughts remove
That spread their darknlng influence DER thee:
Believe me thou ar, still as dear
AS when thou vast III youth and riches.
Oh! wipe away tina; starting tear;
1t Sit IS thy WIFE beseecEcs
Oh. think upon thosc early days,
When thou to STRAIN sung would'st listen,
When thy fond look was my best praise,
And with sweet tears thine eyes would glisten.
Believe me love 'tis still The same,
That fruit IS here tho fall'n the blossom!
Time tempers, but not cools the fame
That burns within the faithful bosom.
There is hought may still beguile,
In joy or grief we're never parted,
And oh could but see thee smile
should not be quite broken hearted.
Oh! cease to heave the struggling sigh!
Oh! dash away that tear my dearest!
Believe me, happier Tia, 5 are nigh;
When night is darkest, dawn is nearest;
Look on our infants artless vile,
That strives to take away thy sorrow,
Can'st thou not from that bab sweet smile,
The ray Of joy 10 cheer thee borrows


There is something in my breast


That says we are not quite forsakcn


That says "nce more we shalt be blest,
And joys soft tone again shall walen.


Prrchlnce the parting beam Of life,


Shal shed peaceful sunshine DER us;


Th n hand in hand we'll quit the strife,


With bright thornless 'ath before us.

full articles.headline:
THE BALLOON.

By Miss Lucy AKIN.
full articles.article:
The airy ship at anchor rides;
Proudly she heaves her painted sides,


Impatient OF delay
And now her silken form expands,
She springs aloft, she bursts her bands.


She floats upon her way.
How swift! for now see her sail
High mounted on the v,ewess gale,


And speeding up the sky,
And now a speck in etner tosl--
A moment seen, a moment lost


She cheats my dazzle,i eye.
Bright wonder, thee no Tapping wing,
No abouring oar. no bounding spring.


Urge ON thy fleet career;
by native buoyalcy lmpclled,
Thy easy fight was smoothly held


Along the silent sphere.
No cuiling mist at close of light,
No meteor on the breast of night,


No cloud at breezy dawn;
No leaf adown the summer tide
More eHortless is seen to glide,


Or shadow DER the lawn.
Yet thee, e'en then, the destined hour
Snail summon from thy airy tower,
With haccid sides that droop forlorn,


Thy breath atherlal spent.
Thus daring fancy's plume sublime
Thus loves bright wings are clippd by time


Thus hope, her soul eate,
Exhales amid this grosscr air.
Thus lghtest hearts are bowed by care,
And genius yields to fate.
